correction_response: This tweet is partially accurate. The average number of countries visited by residents of the UK, Germany, and France aligns with the data [source](https://www.nbcnews.com/better/wellness/5-scientifically-proven-health-benefits-traveling-abroad-n759631). However, the claim that only 29% of Americans have been abroad is misleading. According to a Pew Research Center survey, 71% of U.S. adults have traveled internationally at some point in their lives [source](https://www.pewresearch.org/short-reads/2021/08/12/most-americans-have-traveled-abroad-although-differences-among-demographic-groups-are-large/). It's true that Americans tend to visit fewer countries on average, with most having been to just three [source](https://www.nbcnews.com/better/wellness/5-scientifically-proven-health-benefits-traveling-abroad-n759631).
